tobiko/tripleo/topology.py.message:
this will actually break on a host name like - 'overcloud-novacompiteiha-0' (those are sometimes common)

The node name to group name convertsion , lets give this more attention: 
lets create a function here that takes a hostname and returns the group name , that way we can tweak the function to work in every scenario: 

def group_name_from_host(host_name):  
    # remove -N number from node group name  
    group_name=host_name.rsplit('-',1)[0]  
    # remove 'overcloud' from node group name    
    group_name=group_name.replace('overcloud','')  
    # remove any residual '-' from node group name  
    group_name=group_name.replace('-','')  
    return group_name  
      
              
                    

group_name_from_host('overcloud-novacomputeiha-0')        
'novacomputeiha'

group_name_from_host('controller-0')                         
'controller' 

What do you think ?

Interesting. I didn't tougth to remove the initial 'overcloud-' from the main subgroup name but it makes sense to me.

Let me add such filter then.

gbpautomation/heat/tests/test_grouppolic.message:
I realize that this issue wasn't introduced with this patch, but we probably should only have the patches applied for the tests or test class. For example:

        self.mock_create = mock.patch(
            'gbpclient.v2_0.client.Client.create_application_policy_group')
        self.mock_delete = mock.patch(
            'gbpclient.v2_0.client.Client.delete_application_policy_group')
        self.mock_show = mock.patch(
            'gbpclient.v2_0.client.Client.show_application_policy_group')
        self.mock_update = mock.patch(
            'gbpclient.v2_0.client.Client.update_application_policy_group')
        self.mock_create.start()
        self.mock_delete.start()
        self.mock_show.start()
        self.mock_update.start()
        self.stub_keystoneclient()

And add a tearDown that removes the mocks:
    def tearDown(self):
        self.mock_create.stop()
        self.mock_delete.stop()
        self.mock_show.stop()
        self.mock_update.stop()
        self.stub_keystoneclient()
        super(ApplicationPolicyGroupTest, self).tearDown()

Even better would be to use a context manager for each test, but given the number of changes involved, this might be a good middle-ground.

Anywhere that you've removed the original call parameters, they should be replaced with checks for the expected call parameters. For example:

    expected = mock.call({'application_policy_group': 
        {'shared': True, 'description': u'test APG resource', 
         'name': u'test-application-policy-group'}})
    gbpclient.Client.create_application_policy_group.
        assert_has_calls([expected])


Or alternatively if you use the start/stop for mocks, you would do something like for the last line above:

    _mocked_create = self.mock_create.get_original()[0]
    _mocked_create.assert_has_calls([expected])

This is a nit, so I'm not going to put a minus-1 on it, but whenever you can, try to keep the code as similar as possible in order to help reviewers. In this case, putting the call_dict at the beginning of the function would have matched the dictionary in lines 423-427 of the old code (e.g. similar to what you did in lines 411-417). There are a few of other places in the patch where it does this. Just something to consider in future patches.

It looks like there was a problem with the UT in the original code, but the thing we should be checking is the delete call (i.e. line 449 in the original patch is mocking the show, and we really want the delete checked, since that's what's being tested).

We also should use names that reflect what's being mocked. In other words, it should be something like:

    _mocked_delete = self.mock_delete.get_original()[0]
    _mocked_delete.assert_has_calls([expected])

This naming convention should be applied throughout the patch.
Same comment as above - original UT was probably incorrect, as this should be using mock_delete, not mock_show (plus use correct naming for the mock variables).

I don't think we need this comment. In reading about the call, I"m not sure why they used it, as I don't think it's needed here:

https://pymox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/reference.html#mox.MockMethod.MultipleTimes
same comment as above - test is for delete, so we should be using that instead of show (and change variable names).

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
please explain in more detail about the changes. something like below:

Fix 404 when deleting volume group

In delete_group() method we delete the group first and
then try to fetch the volume information which internally
try to find all the related groups. As group delete request
was placed earlier than volume list and the group might be
deleted before volume list try to find the group
information, it returns 404.

This is race condition based on group is finish its deletion
before list volume requests or not.

Better is to fetch the information of volumes first and then
we need to delete the group. And use that volume info later
to cleanup the volume also if requested.
Done
just curious, which interface calling does this "it" refer to?

When tempest requests volumes details, the cinder wsgi dispatch calls [1] which leads to calling [2] and which leads to calling [3].

[1] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/api/v2/volumes.py#L92
[2] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/api/v3/views/volumes.py#L78
[3] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/api/v2/views/volumes.py#L107
yeah, 'it' refer to tempest delete_group() method L9 which internally make all these requests.

[3] above call get group which leads to calling [4] which throws Not Found Exception

[4] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/db/sqlalchemy/api.py#L5985
do you mean  self.volumes_client.list_volumes?

oh, shouldn't cinder deal with that 404?
For an end user who doesn't know the internal details, listing volumes got a 404 error for group is not found seems weird.

This is a race condition, does not happen every time. I think we are querying the volumes too soon and not giving enough time to clean up. The proposed fix is still doing the same thing and is giving enough time for volumes and groups to clean up.
Cinder.

doc/source/policy.rst.message:
Looking back at this, I actually hit a bug with this the other day that perhaps we should address if we're looking at this.  {{ ansible_architecture }} is looked up on the host, so doesn't actually work as you would like in a hetrogenous situation like bridge.o.o calling out to an arm64 node.  it's always going to x86_64 in that case.

It took me quite a bit of digging to figure out why what I thought was running on arm64 actually wasn't.  It is actually probably worth dropping this bit completely as it's probably generally wrong.

Oh so it's looked up on the controller and not the remote?

I'll take a look at that, there are multiple roles, like ensure-go and ensure-packer, affected by this and needs to be updated if that's the case.
NIT - I'd rather keep these in a specific distros dir for tidiness, as this could potentially represent a fair amount of files, but the naming scheme is clear enough
Sure, to me it doesn't matter but this is how it looks today for a lot of roles. They would need to be updated if we want to stick with that.
NIT - we could take this opportunity to update the example to a more recent version

Did you also look at https://sbarnea.com/ansible/distro-vars/ -- it has few improvements over what we have here:

- lowercased filenames
- layered loading which avoids having to duplicate the same variables on lots of config files, you can define them at the first level they are needed.

You should also mention that the use of "tasks_from" with role inclusion is discouraged because it will prevent loading these variables (likelyadded only to tasks/main.yml). A role should have a single entry point, the main.yaml, calling tasks files directly is more like using private API calls.

> - lowercased filenames

doc/source/admin/shared-file-systems-sha.message:
Could you rewrite this a teeny bit?

Share networks are essential to allow end users a path to hard multi-tenancy. When backed by isolated networks, the Shared File Systems service can guarantee hard network path isolation for the users' shares. Users can be allowed to designate their project networks to share networks. When a share network is provided during share creation, the share driver sets up a virtual share server (NAS server) on the share network and exports shares using this NAS server. The share server itself is abstracted away from the user. You must ensure that the storage system can connect the share servers it provisions to the networks users can use as their share networks. 

.. note::

 Not all shared file systems storage backends support share networks.
 Share networks can only be used when using a share type that has the  
 specification ``driver_handles_share_servers=True``. To see what storage back
 ends support this specification, refer to the 
 :doc:`share_back_ends_feature_support_mapping`.

Yeah. Removed the "or update". Maybe it is better to rephrase this.
I mean, if this is as is, we are considering that the person that is creating the share is not specifying any share type, 'cause if a share type that has dhss=true set is specified during the share creation, the share network will become a mandatory parameter. I know we are mentioning it now in the beginning referencing that share networks can be used when you have a dhss=true env, but may be better to change a bit here as well.
Should we keep this generic as is or modify it?

A default subnet is expected to be reachable from all availability zones in the cloud.
I meant the relationship is 1 share network to many share network subnets. Thinking again, this phrase may not be so necessary here...

If a share network subnet is not assigned a specific availability zone, it is considered to be available across all availability zones. Such a subnet is referred to as a ``default`` subnet. A share network can have only one default subnet. However, having a default subnet is not necessary.

A share network provides a way to designate a network to export shares upon. In the most common use case, you can create a share network with a private OpenStack (neutron) network that you own. networking_opencontrail/repository/utils.message:
I am afraid about the situation where:
1. User creates Virtual Network A
2. User updates Virtual Network A with data X
3. Sync creates Virtual Network A (delayed operation)
4. Sync notices that VN A already exists and updates this with its own version of VN A (we lost data X).

ntf_sync_lock prevents sync from running when event handling is being done. So the delayed operation in 3. can only happen right before the update (the update will then overwrite the object) or right after the update - then, the object being read by sync will have to be the updated version.

The user can change resource name in Neutron so it might be misleading. For example in this situation:

User creates Neutron Object A with name X.
NTF creates TF Object AA with name X-SOME_UUID.
User updates Neutron Object A with name Y.
NTF cannot change TF Object's Name so AA still has name X-SOME_UUID.
User creates Neutron Object B with name X.

Suddenly there is an error with TF Object AA.
The user reads that obj name is X-SOME_UUID so he looks up for a Neutron object with name X. He finds B object which is false.

To avoid that problem we keep the actual Neutron Object Name as TF Display Name. If the user finds an FQ_NAME he will find object's uuid so then he can read this object to find it's display_name.

It's definitely less readable when FQ_NAME contains UUID instead of Name but we will be sure that the Display Name actually matches Name of Neutron Object and that's why I prefer to keep it that way.

Okay, I think I understand, but there's one thing we should be 100% sure of:

When we call foo.wait() (e.g., async_disk_delete.wait()) above, does that return only when the disk is actually deleted (or perhaps when it fails to delete the disk)?.  Put another way, is it the case that .wait() will never return successfully while the underlying resource still exists?

If the answer to those questions is "yes", then I think this is correct as written and we should just change the comment in waitForNodeCleanup to read "All async tasks are handled in cleanupNode".

Otherwise, we'll have to rethink this a bit more.

In either case, I don't think moving everything to waitForNodeCleanup would be advantageous; I think the two methods are only ever called one immediately after the other, so they are really only split for code organization purposes.

There's a .wait() call on virtual_machines.delete() -- does that mean we're waiting for the machine to be deleted, or just waiting for the API call to return, indicating that it received the request?

If we aren't waiting for deletion above, I worry about not implementing this method -- we will end up deleting the znode too quickly and then risk detecting the instance as a leaked instance then creating a new znode for it and deleting that until it is finally deleted.

yes - the `.wait()`s above will only return when it is deleted (or fails).

So, after digging into this a little bit - we need to keep the waits, and do them in a specific order (if we dont wait between server and nic deletion for example, it spins throws errors until the server is deleted).

deploy-guide/source/app-certificate-mana.message: i'm confused on this point. isn't it more that we need the supply Vault with a server certificate and that self-signing a CA cert is just one way to do that? the second option of uploading a certificate (and root CA info) doesn't give Vault the ability to issue further certificates does it?

No this document is about how to set up the PKI engine of Vault to issue certificates on your behalf to the deployment.

This is either done through requesting and uploading a intermediate CA certificate to Vault or by generating a self-signed CA certificate.

This document currently only describes how to enable the Vault PKI engine by uploading the intermediate CA and the aim of this PR is to add the self-signed generate root CA approach.
i think these links are overkill if the next sections cover these topics.

...Certificate Signing Request (CSR) that will then need
to be signed by an external CA. The resulting certificate is uploaded to Vault along with supporting certificate information (root certificate, any intermediary certificates, and the certificate chain).
In light of you initial question the rewording here is loosing important information, we are making Vault into an intermediate certificate authority here.
I think by now we can shorten this to just 'CSR'.
This is the first time the expanded sentence and acronym stand together, but we can surely define the acronym on the first mention a few lines above and make the title shorter.
ok, let's leave it as is

roles/terraform/tasks/main.yaml.message:
It looks like since you hard-coded "line: 1" this is just meant to apply to the entire file?  In that case why not omit it so this becomes a file comment instead of a line comment?  Then the comment will not interrupt the text.

I have some concerns about this approach generally: Given that this is expected behavior, I worry that users may find an inline plan to be a bit noisy.  Especially since a terraform plan is likely to be much longer than the samples here.  Do you have some real world examples/experience to share?

My instinct is to think that is the case and to simply make an artifact entry so that it's easy for users to review the plan in the build logs.

However, after a little research, I see this: https://www.terraform.io/guides/core-workflow.html#plan-1

So apparently that's a recommended practice.

If this is what we want to do, we should probably have an option to turn this off.

Finally, would it be better for this to be a review message rather than a file comment?  I know we don't have that capability, but I don't think it would be hard to add to Zuul if it would be useful.  We can make that change later if we want.

Yes I wanted to make it a review message to start with. But found out that it wasn't possible to do atm.

Didn't know you could just omit the line to get a file comment, so lets do that instead.

deployment/nova/nova-conductor-container.message:
Does this actually require delegation to this particular host, or will using 'run_once: true' be better here?

Currently this runs it multiple times, which is definitely wasteful.
This needs to be delegated if its' an external_upgrade_tasks because they are run on the undercloud. This could be a normal upgrade_task with a run_once instead if we wanted to go with that

actions/actions.py.message:
https://docs.python.org/3/library/subprocess.html#subprocess.CalledProcessError

It looks like e.output is the same as e.stdout, so we're missing e.stderr here. I would concatenate both. What do you think?

On the other hand you just moved that snippet, so feel free to deem this out of scope.

doc/source/install/standalone.rst.message: I wonder if we should mention the required version of keystoneauth
That could get unwieldy if we did it for everything. I've assumed its enough for Victoria documentation works for libraries in the Victoria release
